title: French Film Aesthetics
xlist: Same As: CPLT 920, section 01
description: This seminar examines a range of significant films in the history of the art, downplaying cultural context and focusing on style and structure. How have the most "standout" films since D.W. Griffith used the medium? Because this art was more actively taken up by intellectuals in France than elsewhere, and because of the flourishing film culture there, critical terminology all over the world is peppered with French terms. A geneaology of those terms guides our entry into aesthetic issues in the history not just of French cinema but of the art overall. The seminar is broken into three broad modules, each dealing with a set of related French terms that open up various parts of cinema and of filmmaking. Module 1: Artistic Agency: auteur, caméra-stylo, écriture, cinéma impur, cinéma de qualité; Module 2: Aesthetic Technique: montage/d%eacute;coupage, mise-en-scène/plan-séquence, cadre/cache/décadrage, suture/hors champ; Module 3: Cinematic Specificity: photogénie, dispositif, trace/figure. Participants help further establish the genealogy of one or more terms; exemplify an historical or current practice involving one of these terms; and write a significant term paper launching from the premises of the seminar.
